title: Extruder for 1.75mm filament with splined model-car insert as pinch wheel

description.text: This is a derivative based on a Wade Nema 17 extruder. It uses a splined model-car insert as pinch wheel... The axis is M4 and the bearings are 624 for axis and 608 for the idler...

This thing is working as you can see more or less on my figures. However, for a second version, I would change some things which are not comfortable enough: First, I would make an accessable extruder, with a quick release idler block. Second, the slots for the motor drive are not perfect, that means you cannot slide the motor when it is mounted (hence difficult to assemble). Third, a gear set is needed... I used a hering bone gear set. (On the figure you can see the extruder with a mounted adapter plate... that plate is not part of the extruder. The extruder will fit on a standard mendel x carriage) Instructions: 1) Print the parts base.STL and idler.STL
2) Get
2 624 bearings
1 608 bearing
1 M4 axis for pinch wheel
4 M4 spacer
1 M4 model splined model car insert (see figure)
1 M8 axis for idler
1 Nema17 stepper
4 M3 screws
1 * M4 nut
3) assemble the whole thing (see figures...)
4) enjoy :)

description.text:
Sensibo (www.sensibo.com) pods control wall mount Air Conditioners using remote IR signals from a POD mounted close by. The PODs transmit via multiple IR emitting LEDs pointed in all directions. This mask helps if you need your pod to be a little more directional. This is useful for cases where you have two separate ACs using separate pods in close proximity.

Just print and slip the cover on your pod and adjust the window towards the unit you would like to receive the IR signals.

Printer:

Rapide LITE 200 XL

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed with 100% infill using black PLA. It gave great results for ACs in a near by rooming that were responding to reflected signals.

The model isn't perfect - needs support for a floating rim, it worked well with my printer but YMMV. The rim helps lock the print to the Sensibo.

Sensibo (www.sensibo.com) pods control wall mount Air Conditioners using remote IR signals from a POD mounted close by.

This is an angled replacement base for the sensibo pod. Due to the design of the front panel of my Air Conditioners I needed to angle the pod to be able send the IR signals to the AC's receiver.

Printer:

Rapide LITE 200 XL

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

10%

To install the base

Remove the battery cover
Remove the QR code base piece to reveal a locking pin
Remove the locking pin and the bottom base piece that we will be replacing with the print
Install the new base piece, locking pin and QR code base piece
Reinstall the battery cover

title: Telescope XBox Live Vision camera case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There are two case variants, the "Air" one can be used with/without fan and has vent holes, and the "Plain" one is for using without fan and is fully closed.

I use a 5v 40x40x10mm fan powered from the same USB line, pulling air from the case.
As previously said you can use the holed case with or without the fan. If you want the fan, you need four M3x30mm bolts else you need four M3x16mm bolts as clossing hardware.

Assembling notes:

Before assembling the PCB:

-Use a 3mm drill for remove the self contained support layer on the four main bolt holes on the rear part.

-Use the same M3 bolts fo create the thread on the front plastic part.

-Use the two original PCB screws for create the threaded holes on the PCB support, rear part.

-Superglue the 125Adapter you want to the front part.
You have two 1.25 inch adapter options:
125AdapterShort is 20.4mm length (+7mm of the filter ring= 25.4mm or 1inch)
125Adapter is 31mm length (+7mm of the filter ring=38mm) and the

-Superglue a standard 1.25'' filter ring (without the glass) to the 125Adapter, this can be used as thread for an easy removable IR cut or color filters.

-Please share your results!

----- UPDATES -----
Jan/14/17: Added 125AdapterShort.
Jan/04/2017: Updated dustCapV2 file. Updated renders.

Contribute by donating:

This designs has a lot of effort and testings, so please if you like it and found usefull consider to make a donation, any amount will be really apreciate and you will contributing with improved and future designs.

You can donate here: http://villamanydonate.blogspot.com

Thank you!

author: filamentsdirectory

description.text:
There are a lot of very nice Z-screw accessories out there, but this one is bog-simple. Print it off, then snug it into the z-screw hole at the top of the frame. It should fit slightly snugly on the z-screw and rotate with a slight amount of friction in the socket on the frame. Sand it a little if it binds. This is not as robust as one with a bearing, but it does work and reduces play to next to nothing. This is specifically for a Hesine Prusa i3, but the same concept should work for any printer that simply has a hole in the top of the frame that the z-screw goes through.

edit: I just noticed http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2009680 for something to customize the idea for your particular printer, a much more useful thing than my ultra-specific one.

comments.text:
Simple but useless. Worse, often leads to more wobble.
Funny but the worst ideas seem to get the most appraisals !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Perhaps, but it works for me. The unsupported top of the z-axis screw often resulted in vertical errors for me and the prints after I put in this bushing are as perfect as this printer can do. And if you make it and it does not work for you, you just pull it off and you are none the worse for wear!

I identified 3 families of magic solutions, from bad to almost OK. Yours is in the bad one.

This is a proof of concept of an XY table, similar to the one Tekma3D printers use, but almost fully 3d printed. The only hardware you will need are some M3 Screws and M3 threaded rod (optional) to reinforce the spindles.
Print each part as stated in each file name, glue the spline halves together and add the threaded rod in between if you wish. Then glue the end piece and the motor coupler to each end as seen in the photographs. This motor coupler was designed for some steppers I took out of a laser printer, but can be fixed to a nema 17 with some tape, or glue it in place.
I encourage you to design your own if you want to print this.
Asemble the racks as seen in the photographs, and there you go!
It will not be the most rigid or precise machine ever, but it does work well enough for a pen plotter or perhaps a chocolate printer?

More projects here: https://juanggengineering.blogspot.ca

Hardware:

This runs on grbl. Check my A4 Pen Plotter (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2504587) for more instructions on this.

comments.text: Nice idea. None of the servos will have to move with the table, reducing their vibration, increasing their lifespan, and eliminating the need for a continuously flexing cable. Put a printer head on top of that and you're good to go.

author: ocannady

title: Yet another AA battery case 8x4 and 8x2 - Mk2

description.text:
Another iteration of battery case, features

  • smaller 2x4 case has support for 5x3mm magnets. (i think the magnets are not great for some batteries, so for the longer storage the bigger 8x4 box has no support for the magnets)

  • can store decent amount of batteries 8x4

  • if you want save on filament and don't need firm and steady case, then you can use the top case to hold the batteries, as shown in the photo above.

  • should be printer friendly (no holes like last revision), the printer does nice continuous movements and no sharp turns, so it's easy to get first layer sticking and to make all layers adhere well. Probably it should be possible to print at faster speeds

  • from Mk1 the marking which indicates what batteries are full or empty was removed, it's pretty easy to remember that when battery is upright it will be ready to use, while upside down needs to be recharged.

  • changed from Mk1 the top and bottom are not equally high, but the bottom is around3/4 of the battery size. So if I want to store batteries at home in a drawer and will not travel probably I don't need to print the top and still the batteries will be stored well enough (one side is always insulated so no short circuits / other damage possible).

  • the casing fit nicely around itself, should be possible to print multiple of them and glue them together like hexagonal cells to allow different combinations

  • tried few attempts to get the dimensions just right, now it's tight enough to keep them firm and steady, while still have them lose enough to allow the batteries be removed with ease.

Because to conceal the holes only 1 layer is used, to save on filament where you don't need it, it's good to have verified that your 1st layer will print well and you don't need to do any rafts or anything. Some designs have holes for the dimples, this is similar only it prints better and cover the batteries.

Mk1 is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1796360
It has some different design decisions, after while I don't like them, but somebody maybe will so have a look, but I still think this is a better version to print.

title: Complements for stevenson screen for DHT11

description.text:
I needed a support to fix this stevenson screen so I designed one using freecad. You just have to bolt the support to a box (using M3 screws), then put the stevenson screeen on it.
I also designed a washer (named "cale", which means washer in french ;): because I first printed the 6mm version of the screen, then decided to use the 11mm version instead. So, instead of printed again the elements I already printed, I designed this little spacer to adapt the 6mm screens to the 11mm screens.
I printed this screen in white PLA, but you should better use ABS if you wish it to last more.
Feel free to edit / use the freecad file I provided.

Only three simple 3D printed parts link a servo to a stepper motor and make a data plotter.
Ideal for 24 hours a day registration of temperature, humidity or whatever. The stepper motor shaft has an adapter so an old CD or DVD can be clamped on it. The stepper motor will rotate at constant speed, depending on the time interval that needs to be covered during one rotation. The servo motor follows the value of the parameter to be measured and drives the pen holder.
Not interested in physics? Use it as a spirograph.

A stencil with the symbols used in Montessori classrooms for sentence grammar exercises. I used this stencil to force me to learn how to create objects in OpenSCAD. The stencil is playing card size, and has rounded corners. The OpenSCAD file is available for download and customization.

  • Large circle (red) => verb
  • Small circle (orange) => adverb
  • Crescent moon (green) => preposition
  • Small rectangle (pink) => conjunction
  • Keyhole (yellow) => interjection
  • Small equilateral triangle (light blue) => article
  • Medium equilateral triangle (dark blue) => adjective
  • Large equilateral triangle (black) => noun
  • Large isosceles triangle (purple) => pronoun

Printer:

mp mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No
OpenSCAD
Overview Helps associate a symbol and a color to sentence grammar constructs to give a visual way to identify sentence diagramming.

Activity
  • Explain the associations between words and symbols/colors
  • Write sentences using multiple word types
  • Using the stencil draw the associated shape above the word
  • Show patterns of sentence structure using the shapes as a visual queue

Materials
  • Colored pencils
  • Paper
  • Stencil

description.text: I got sick of trying to use my drill press as a lathe in my attempts to build my extruder, so I threw this together in SolidWorks.  I used 1/4" and 3/8" acrylic for most of it.  There are three pieces of 3/4" HDPE for slides.  It has 12 X 1/4-20 hex nuts, 36" of 1/4-20 threaded rod, two plastic knobs, and the drive assembly from a cordless drill.  I left off the tailstock, live center, and cutting tool plate, but those can be easily fabricated.  Use it at your own risk.  I uploaded some pictures of the finished lathe and my first completely successful part.  The lathe isn't the perfect solution, but it get's the job done.

author: hlandre

description.text:
A bracket for a filament spool shelf or rack.
I used 3 of them for a 1 meter wide shelf.
I used 2 round wooden broomsticks as carriers. You can used anything with 25 mm diameter or less. I also took 2.5 mm thick steel wires and glued them into the small hole. This makes the plastic bracket much ore stable.

The wall mounting holes have a central to center distance of 85 mm.
Cut out the 2 supporting ribs, that separate the round hole from the slot.
This allows you to screw a regular 3 or 3.5 mm screw into the wall, slide the bracket over the screw heads and just pull them down a bit to get the screws into the slots.

comments.text: Great design! I have no doubt it would work really well....however will be too big to print on most printers.(mine included). This would need at least a 250 mm x 250mm plate.
comments.author: Tadly

comments.text:
Actually the size is 222 x 134 mm.
I have 3 printers and I can print it on any of them. So I did not care too much about smaller printers, to be honest.
I wanted to be able to store up to 250 mm spool size, so the center needs to be 125 mm away from the wall. Actual design is 126 mm. I also wanted the 250 mm spool to stay between the round rods safely. With the current distance, a 250 mm spool "snaps" down approx 10 mm when pushed over the first rod. This maybe could be reduced a bit. If we move the outer rod in by 25 mm, in order to get the design under 200 mm, then the spool size is limited to 238 mm and it snaps in around 3.5 mm.
comments.author: Tadly

description.text:
Vacuum outlet diffuser for 2.25in (~58mm) vacuum outlet to redirect air flow and minimize debris being kicked up by the vacuum outlet. This diffuser will not effect the sound of the vacuum, and is not a sound dampener. This diffuser did not appear to reduce the vacuum inlet pressure.

A project to learn how to use OpenSCAD. Not as fancy as this ShopVac Diffuser but seems to work just fine. The fit in my vacuum is not snug, but it does not shoot out when the vacuum is on. A wrap of tape would probably give it a snug fit if that is needed. A filter mesh could probably be fitted inside if that was needed.

Printer:

mp mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Final height is 115mm, had to stay under 120mm which is the max size for my printer.

OpenSCAD

Used digital calipers to measure the outlet hole in my vacuum. Within OpenSCAD created the holes using nested 'for' loops to place cylinders for the holes in the body wall and base. Went through several iterations, I initially started with too many holes in the base and the blast was too strong, so ended up with smaller and fewer holes in the base to direct the air to the sides. Found the air to be dissipated to the touch within about 1 foot from the diffuser.

description.text:
This is a stand designed to hold a dead insect or arachnid preserved in a block of plastic. The central holder is sized for a 24mm x 36mm keyring sample that was popular a while ago, and has a hole for a neopixel. A 50mm diameter magnifier can be mounted in a detachable mount held on with 4 telescopic antennas. There are also 2 mounts in the base for spirit level tubes (I sized them for the tubes from a poundland laser level), with holes for 3mm leds to make the tubes glow. In the base section, there are hollow walls that can be filled with putty or resin to add some weight if needed.

The parts are cut to avoid overhang so they should come out ok even on difficult printers, but to complete the build, a few non-printed parts are needed.

remixed_from.author: iamjonlawrence
remixed_from.title: Timing Belt X MXL, Printrbot Simple V2

title: Double Precision MXL X-Axis, Printrbot Simple V2

description.text: This is for the Simple V2 w/o String tension. AFTER 10/23/2013 Printrbot added the string tension device and the mounting locations changed and will not line up with this design. If you want high quality parts than this is your ticket. This produces super smooth parts. The maximum speed is limited to about 50mm/sec due to a limitation of the number of steps/sec. the printrboard can output. Not too bad really since the posted limits of the Simple are 60-65. On the up side you can more than double your acceleration and XY Jerk settings, so overall print time is about equal if not better plus smoother prints! The motor mount plate, bearings, and tie bar are the same as the previous MXL X-Axis drive: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:191706 2013-12-24, REV A: Updated part number for longer belt. This one part number will give you enough length for both X and Y upgrades.

• The calibration values should be around 210 steps / mm.
  • A tip to get the belt length correct: Only secure the bearing holder for the 624 bearing temporarily at first, string up your belt, mark where it passes thru the belt tension block, then remove the 624 bearing holder to give you extra length to fold the belt back over itself.

comments.text:
I would recommend the GT2 upgrade: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:194686http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
You may be able to double stack bearings and get lucky, but I think the belt will not track correctly.
What is the worst case, it doesn't work and you have to try again? This is why I try to not require any modification of stock parts. You can always go back if something doesn't work.
Maybe print out both this thing and the GT2, and see what works best. That way you have a backup plan and don't have to put the string back on.

comments.text: I assembled the X and Y axes after the longer belts arrived, and made my first few prints last night.  The first thing I ran into was belts slipping in the tensioning blocks -- I couldn't get them wedged tightly, so I couldn't tighten things.  So, the first thing I printed was some belt clamps.  (I'll post a link to the STL for that when I get home, plus some pictures of the MXL pieces.)
comments.author: spacewrench

comments.text: The parts I printed were on the old, single-resolution printer, and the belt channels were too small to fit a doubled, interlaced belt.  I was trying to jam them in there with stubs of zip-ties and stuff, but it didn't work very well so I made the belt clamps.  Maybe I'll re-print the tension blocks -- it sounds like your securing mechanism would be really clean, if I could get everything to fit.
comments.author: iamjonlawrence

comments.text: Yep, I think it was the electronic limit.  I set all the feed rates to 50mm/sec or below, then reprinted the Y-axis front bearing block.  Nice clean print, no jumping around.  I think I can design an improved Y axis tension block with teeth to clamp the belt (instead of your fold-over-and jam mechanism).  I'll have to think about the X axis tensioner some more, though.

comments.text: I printed this and the Y-axis design, and got the parts from McMaster for about $100.  However, the MMC part number for the belt is too short -- your note says 21" minimum length, but that belt is only 17".  You probably need 1679K671 or 1679K674.

My apologies on the part number, it was a carryover from the original version and incorrect for the double precision.
I would suggest ordering 1679K684 (77" belt) as it gives you the most bang for the buck and it will be cut it to length anyway. Spare belt always comes in handy.

I have a cat tree that the plastic portion that holds a column upright broke. The original plastic was thin and failed from an 8lb cat's use. The column slides over the support, and the support is held to the platform by a captured nut. The column inside diameter is 60mm, the support will fit, but for me it was very snug so I ended up sanding the outside of the support to allow a little more room.

This was one of my first adventures with OpenSCAD so I probably went a bit overboard on the thicknesses but it is very sturdy.

The nut cavity is 15.6mm at its widest, not sure what size nut that makes it, but it seems very standard for the cat trees I have assembled.

To install drop the nut into the supports nut cavity, and slide over the bolt until they connect. Next twist the support so that the threads are captured by the nut until the support is snug against the base. Finally slide the column over the support.

description.text:
This is a hinged top lack enclosure that also has two opening doors. Standard size lack table legs have been used but each part here raises the height by 30mm to give more clearance to the top of the printer.
There are a number of parts, but should all be generally easy to work out, but ask if you have any questions

Updated 26/02/207 to add larger gapped corners with 3mm gaps for glass instead of 2.5mm, these are labelled _3mm at the end of the file names.

Printer:

Prusa3d I3 Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Printing - Assembly - General

This is designed to use only 3 of the 4 legs that come with an IKEA Lack table. You will need two tables and just 3 of the legs from one. You can of course modify to your hearts content and raise it with the other legs etc
Each leg has 3 pieces, a leg base, a leg top, and a top plate that fixes to the lid. The left and right lower legs also have a hole for a bearing with an outside diameter of 16mm and inner hole of 5mm. The door hinges are made to sit in this middle hole of the bearing nice a snug. The hinges can have a screw put through the 2mm polycarbonate to keep secure or glued if wanted.
The door frames are just clip on edges to make the polycarbonate look nice. The door handles are printed in two parts, I used acetone on them (ABS) to weld them together afterwards.
The filament feed channel is flimsy when printed but made to fit together through the table top and has a little lip to allow you to glue it in place.
The cable grommets print as a nice snug fit and can be screwed together or just left clipped together, they won't move but have made them so they can be screwed if needed.
The cable clips are the same dimensions as the door frames and I used them also on top of the polycarbonate on the sides, I used the clips in between the frame edges to run cables around to keep it neat on the inside.

title: X and Y Limit Switch Spacers -  JGAurora A-3

description.text:
These spacers are designed to properly position the nozzle over the print bed rather than in the air to the front/left of the bed. The x spacer just snaps to the rod and slides to the left into a pocket in the existing bracket. The y spacer slips on to the rear of the lower bed plate just in line with the limit switch. (Make sure this clip is clear of other printer parts as the bed slides through its travel.)

Now when you "Auto Home", the x and y limit switches will contact these spacers and position the print nozzle over the bed at the front left corner. This prevents the need to alter G-code to re-zero over the bed.

Without proper zeroing, the printer will skew its print to the left and front resulting in:

  • An off-center print.
  • Loss of usable space along the right and rear portions of the bed.
  • The potential to print in the air to the left and in front of the bed.

title: Shower Caddy Suction Cup Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Our Ventana Motor Coach has a corner shower. There is a custom shelf in the corner for shampoo, etc...but we needed more space. We installed a typical Shower Caddy like you find in Lowe's or Home Depot. The problem is...the suction cups, as it comes...are off the edge of the molding on our shower. The result...no suction. This THING is designed to relocate the suction cups to a location that will adhere to the shower stall moulding...and provide better security for the shower caddy. Works nicely...shower caddy is now very stable.

Note: The little wire rectangles just above the new clips are where the suction cups were originally located. That position overlaps the edge of the moulding...preventing a seal.

The design was sliced with Simplify3D...and replicated once and then mirrored on the x axis to create a left and right version.

author: daktylus

title: filament sensor switchbox remix (for maplin roller microswitch)

description.text:
The original Thing by bookmake was nearly a perfect fit for Maplin's "Minature Microswitch with Roller" (Maplin product code N97AQ), except the gap for the lever arm and roller wasn't quite right - didn't extend far enough towards the left.

So, I took their STL in to Fusion360, cut away a bunch of the "out" side of the filament guide path. A test print revealed that the part was also a little too small along the Y-axis such that the switch was being clicked just by putting the microswitch in to position, so I stretched out the space between switch-holder and filament path by 1.5mm to solve that. (The part is not just rescaled in whole - I cut it in a couple of places and stretched just the necessary area.)

Unfortunately I wasn't able to get Fusion to behave to resize the lid in the same way, so I just trimmed it back. It still works (the lid helps hold the switch in place), so I've called it "good enough".

I have added a further variant file, with an open slot in the base box for wiring (rather than a hole) to give the option of not having soldered wires "tie" the box to your wiring. The same lid still works and nicely keeps the wires in place, it's just easier to work with.

I will be wiring the switch up to my Raspberry Pi running OctoPrint and using the filament sensor plugin to get prints to automatically pause at run-out.

The original snapped together really nicely and I think I've managed to not ruin that part of the design.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm z height

Infill:

30% Cubic in Slic3r

comments.text: do you have this working with the plug in?
comments.author: mickw99

comments.text: I ended up using the "Filament Sensor Reloaded" plugin, which gives a nice settings UI section. I'm sending an M600 gcode when the sensor trips, as that puts my Original Prusa i3 mk2 in to a nice pause-to-change-filament state. Make sure to tell Octoprint that this is a long-running command or it will very likely give up on waiting for the printer and abort your print with a timeout error.

title: M5 Square Nut Holder for OpenBuilds V-Slot

description.text:
During the build of my J-Bot the M5 square nuts often left damage on the v-slot when over tightened. They were also difficult to start to thread if the M5 screw wasn't quite long enough or if the nut wasn't sitting parallel to the face of the extrusion. These inserts help prevent both problems. The only negative is that they must be inserted from the ends of the rail.

Ultimately I think the pre-assembly t-nuts are probably the best way to go, but if you already have the square nuts then these can help solve the issues mentioned above.

comments.text: What hardness of TPE did you use? I have NinjaFlex TPE with a durometer of 85A, it flexes quite a bit. Some things I've done in other past prints with things that don't fit quite right: If it's PLA you can put it in hot water and actually stretch the plastic if it is not too thick. Maybe try that with the tires so that they expand and hopefully can slip them on. Otherwise you might try re-scaling the tires in the x and y axis.

print_settings.Notes:: Holes in the bottom layers print undersized on my printer so they are oversized in the model. If you printer prints true size holes in the bottom layer you may need to decrease hole_radius. The goal is to have pinholes so you balance the flow of the 1/4" hose with the output and maintain spray pressure. Of course, if you want a weaker spray you could always increase the hole size.

description.text:
I created this simple spray nozzle to plug in to a 1/4" quick disconnect ball valve to use as a little sprayer for plants.

The SCAD file can be customized for different connection sizes, face sizes and hole sizes. If you change the face size some minor edits will be required to add more holes but everything is commented and should be clear.

No supports are required.

Update: I added a version of the files tweaked to be printed with "spiralize" mode in Cura. I was having problems with the nozzle breaking off at a layer boundary if it got dropped and spiralize seems to result in a stronger part.

Printing in ABS then acetone vapor smoothing it may also result in a stronger part because the shell layers will be better fused.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

Printed in ABS with 0.2 mm layer height, 20% infill 1.5 mm shell thickness. No support required.

Holes in the bottom layers print undersized on my printer so they are oversized in the model. If you printer prints true size holes in the bottom layer you may need to decrease hole_radius. The goal is to have pinholes so you balance the flow of the 1/4" hose with the output and maintain spray pressure. Of course, if you want a weaker spray you could always increase the hole size.
Created programmatically with OpenSCAD (I'm a software dev so I'm more comfortable in that than 3d modeling programs).

title: Arcade metal control panel button fillers

description.text:
Here is a useful model for printing button hole fillers for metal arcade control panels. Just pop them in from the back, and cover the back with duck tape or something to keep them from falling out from the back (they will not go forward as they are designed larger in the back so they won't go through.).

This design keeps them flush on the front so control panel overlay can be applied without having visible "bumps". you could put them in with the larger side on top instead of the bottom and then no tape would be needed, however then they won't be flush for when control panel overlay is applied.

title: Segway Robotic Wine and Cheese Butler

description.text:
Segway Sommelier De Fromage, a wine-and cheese party attachment for the bluetooth-controlled Ninebot Mini-Pro by Segway. A wine bottle can be stored in the vertical tube.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X5RDpokrU-I

Can be configures in other ways, such as this Christmas Party stack:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SaskLXJT4Jg

Print 6 of the wineglass arms and snap them together, rotated at 60 degree intervals. There are long marker lines every 60 degrees on the outside of the tube to help get the orientation right. If you wish to try different rotations, there are also short tics at 45 degree increments. If your glasses are heavy you may wish to hot-glue the arm segments together to make the stack more rigid.

The base just slips over the Segway steering column after you remove the kneepad assembly. The fit is deliberately loose so use a couple of shims to keep the base from rattling.

Glue a lightweight serving platter onto either the wide or narrow tray mount piece. Fake-chrome plastic platters from party supply places work well, but I have also used small stamped-metal platters.

I have tried a double-height stack holding 12 glasses spiraling up through two rotations, but the mini bot becomes alarmingly unstable if the center of gravity gets too high. I stopped my trials before any catastrophes with broken glass, but the double-height stack is admittedly even more impressive than the single -height stack.

author: torreyproctor

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1997468

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1997468

I live aboard an older boat. One of the reasons I own a 3d printer is so that I might fix some of the things around the boat.

This is one such thing.

This is a clip used to hold glass in place - typically found holding mirrors to walls, for example.

This is a simple fountain pen holder, where each "level" consists of two side pieces, and two face pieces.

Files:

  • pen_display.rld -- This is the file for the laser, specifically Chinese lasers.
  • face.dxf and side.dxf -- These are the dxf files. They should work with any laser and cnc machine.
  • face.sldrpt and side.sldrpt -- These are the Solidworks files, which can be edited.

Note that these only work with materials with a thickness of 4mm. You'd have to edit the models for it to work with different thicknesses.

These were made by Reddit user /u/joeydoesntsharefood, I'm posting them here with his permission.

Enjoy! I hope people will find these useful!

description.text:
A handle for regular mouth mason jars. I designed this as part of a gift to be used with hot chocolate I sent with the jars. Must be printed in ABS for use with warm/hot liquids or the handle will soften. Designed to be mounted from the top as illustrated in the pictures.

The clip-on feature is intended to keep the handle below where your mouth meets the jar and the short handle are intended for fast printing of many of these.

Left me know if there are any requests for improving the design.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25

Notes:

Must use ABS for hot drinks, tested with PLA - it softens and will come off when on a warm/hot jar that is filled. The glass transition temperature of PLA is too low to be used warm.
Repeated removal of the handle will start wearing off strands if printed coarsely (.3mm) with weakly bonded ABS, so better resolution and appropriate print temperature for good layer bonding will minimize wear.
Also as a reminder, ABS is not rated as food safe so it is recommend to not send it through the dishwasher.

Print upside down, prints well without raft, and with a bit of support between top of handle and the platform.

Minimal Cleanup.

minimal support under the handle should come off readily with finger motion.
Some of the iterations shown here. Fusion 360 for the win.

title: Spool holder for original Prusa i3 MK2

description.text: I really like my original Prusa i3 MK2 a lot. However, the spool holders are not my favorite solution. So I just created my own. My part is quite a bit thicker than the original part and instead of using integrated plastic bolt stubs, it just has holes that accept any 10 mm rod. I use a steel rod myself. The holding arm also has a 2,7 mm hole from the bottom. You can screw in an M3 screw in order to clamp the spool holder on the i3 frame. I just use M3 Allen screws and tighten them by hand. Works great for me.

2204 protector

This project allows you to write on the spherical surfaces such as Christmas balls or eggs.
This machine is in fact known in the internet as Eggbot or Spherebot . More info
http://www.open-electronics.org/spherebot-reloaded-customize-your-xmas/ Video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ofufxmm6wd4

The mechanics
The mechanical part is composed of parts made with a 3D printer , by some threaded rods and a pair of bearings.
Compared to the versions available on the net, our spherebot presents "print area" greater , so you can draw even on christmas balls with a diameter of 7/8 inches.
You can download and modify also Sketchup files to make it bigger or smaller. The software
As most of the numerical control machines also our spherebot is able to handle the codes Gcode.
A usable software can be downloaded from here or Github
https://github.com/thunderbug1/Spherebot-Host-GUI
and has a nice user interface. The software is very intuitive and also allows you to move all three engines to properly position the marker. Getting the Gcode file
To be able to turn your ideas into prints, need to go through a simple sofware conversion, capable of transforming into Gcode your design or text.
A free software that can help you is INKSCAPE
http://inkscape.org/
The special feature of this software is that it can be modified and adapted to the various needs through scripts written in python .
Once again the comunity helped us and made available an extension to export our image vector in Gcode. In the download section you can download the plugin, which is the same that are available on Github
https://github.com/martymcguire/inkscape-unicorn
Installation is simple, just copy the files located under the SRC folder, under the extensions folder of Inkscape , usually C:\Programfiles\Inkscape\share\extensions
Restart Inkscape and the extension is installed . To transform a written into Gcode is necessary create a path that our marker must follow in order to achieve the inscription. From the Path menu select the item from the object to track.
Now save the file in Gcode: from the menu File select Save as and save the file with the extension *.Gcode .
Confirming it will open a window where we can define some parameters such as the speed, the angle that defines the pen raised , lowered , and other parameters . The electronics
The spherebot is composed of two stepper motors and a servo.
A motor is used to rotate the ball on the axis , the second motor allows to move the marker around the circumference of the sphere.
The servomotor finally serves to raise and lower the pen.
In addition, to allow anyone to easily edit the software without the need for programmers or compilers would be ideal to have a board based on the Arduino .
All of these needs are met by the board of the printer 3Drag.
http://www.open-electronics.org/a-new-board-for-the-3drag-theres-more-than-sanguinololu/
http://www.open-electronics.org/?s=3drag The firmware
Being an open source project did not have to write all the code, but it was enough to find someone who worked there and make any changes.
A big hand has given it Eberhard Rensch
http://pleasantsoftware.com/developer/3d
We desired, however, that the sketch also worked with the latest Arduino IDE (version > 1.0) so we had to modify it a bit. In the Download section you will find the firmware.
The sketch is concerned directly manage the two stepper motors and servo according to the commands received GCode via the USB port. The combination of the three engines allows you to write on the ball without any problems. More info
http://www.open-electronics.org/spherebot-reloaded-customize-your-xmas/

comments.text: Does anyone have the BoM for this project?  BoM  = A bill of materials or product structure (sometimes bill of material, BOM or associated list) is a list of the raw materials, sub-assemblies, intermediate assemblies, sub-components, parts and the quantities of each needed to manufacture an end product. A BOM may be used for communication between manufacturing partners, or confined to a single manufacturing plant. A bill of materials is often tied to a production order whose issuance may generate reservations for components in the bill of materials that are in stock and requisitions for components that are not in stock.

title: Sega Saturn Rhea/Phoebe SD Card Tray V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you'd like to order one of these printed, they are available through my website: https://bit-district.com/console/sega-saturn/phoebe-/-rhea-sd-card-tray.html

The Rhea and Phoebe are SD card adapters that replace the ever failing disc drives in Sega Saturn consoles. These are great devices but they leave a very large space open inside the console meaning you can easily, accidentally drop your SD card inside the console and be forced to disassemble it to get the card back. This SD card Tray is designed to fit around the Rhea or Phoebe device and seal off the inside of the console making it impossible to drop your SD card inside through an open lid.

This is a new version of my original Rhea/Phoebe Tray: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1546926 and address some fitment issues that tray had with certain consoles.

There are two STL files, one is the "base" that should be installed below the Rhea or Phoebe device. The other is the "shield which sits on top of the device and should fit securely into the top of the Sega Saturn case.

Fitment has been tested on VA0 and VA1 console revisions with a Rehea version 3.1. Other console and Rhea/Phoebe version should work as they are dimensionally similar, however if you use this file I would appreciate a comment confirming fitment on other revisions.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

One small support for the cut-out in the center of the "shield" piece may be necessary. The "base" piece should not require any supports.

If you've already installed a Rhea or Phoebe device in your Sega Saturn then installation using the pics above should be self-explanatory.

There is an optional screw hole that allows for inserting a single screw in from the bottom (as show in the pictures above). It's designed to use a screw similar in size to those that hold the Saturn Case together (small enough to fit through hole in the base and the PCB but thread into the shield. This is not at all necessary as everything should fit securely without this.

comments.text:
Here to confirm that fitment works fine on my Type 3 VA7 Saturn with Phoebe.
This is using only the front support peg for the Phoebe unit.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is just a little fix for the magnificent Prusa i3 MK2: V1 Raspberry Pi Camera Mount - The Round Tower by Martin Majewski.

When inserting the camera into the holder, the original holder was too tight for the camera (Amazon US, DE). It bent and broke. I measured the camera and found that the rest for the camera was too narrow. Maybe the manufacturer has changed the proportions of the camera slightly.

I modeled the camera holder after the original STL and fitted it to my needs. Now the camera rest is 5mm wide instead of 4 mm. Fusion 360 file is included for your own customization.

For print settings please refer to the original thing.

author: beckflash

remixed_from.author: Mrcleanr6
remixed_from.title: makergear m2 z axis knob and matching lock

title: MakerGear M2 Z Axis Knob - Spiral

description.text:
This is inspired by Mrclean6's makergear m2 z axis knob.

I used a long set screw (from my local ACE) in the original M2 knob's steel lock collar, the length of the set screw keeps the steel lock collar from moving inside the knob. You can just see the set screw's head in the lower left of the photo.

I used some very elegant (or inelegant, it might be argued) Open SCAD for loops to make the spirals. This means that there are about a billion spheres in the design. So the STL is huge and the Open SCAD render step is formidable.

Frankly, Open SCAD has trouble with the complexity level. I ended up rendering it to STL using a spare server -- Open SCAD took something like 26 hours and many gigs of memory, but it did render in the end, and that is the 261MB STL in the zip.

You can mess with the Open SCAD source in the attached zip, or just import the huge STL from the zip into your slicer.

print_settings.Notes:: Filamentum PLA Extrafill "Gold Happens"

description.text:
I have many fond memories of movie nights with family growing up. Krull seals a spot as one of my favorites of all time. With all the craze over fidget toys cropping up, I was inspired to create a spinner of my own based on the infamous glaive. Like in the movie, I wanted to add a bit of magic; fortunately, you don't have to insert your hand into molten lava for this one!

See it in action!!

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used Filamentum PLA Extrafill "Gold Happens". See Assembly & Printing for further instructions on when to pause for assembly.

Stuff you need
  • (5) 3/16" x 1" Woodruff keys (polish them if you want shiny blades) - Amazon
  • (5) .11" x .3" Neodynium disc magnets
  • (1) 608 Skate bearing
  • Super glue
Oooo... shiny. You will need to pause your print at various heights during your print to assemble.

Insert magnets at 5.8mm. Dab some glue in each hole to prevent the magnets from popping out during print (let the glue set). Also, I pull from the stack without flipping them so the poles are all facing the same direction.

NOTE: you may want to shut off your heat bed as it will interact with the magnets and cause them to vibrate or flip profusely.

Insert Woodruff keys at 7mm. Prior to inserting the keys, I recommend cleaning out any debri or imperfections from printing in the channels for them to slide with ease. The idea is to get the blades (keys) to retract on their own. Be careful while cleaning you don't pop the part off. Do'h!

Completed print, can you figure out how I got the pattern??

Press the 608 skate bearing into place and give it a spin! Don't be surprised if the blades (keys) remain out at first, little bit of a break-in period to smooth things out will get them operating with ease.

Finally

Glue the thumbpads into place and give it a spin!
I used some modeling paint and fingernail polish to give it an inspired design based on the movie prop.
Yeeeah, this was an earlier prototype the keys were too tight so I had to tear it apart. Wasn't pretty.

comments.text: It is surprisingly difficult to find a pack of woodruff keys around the Boulder CO area. Home Depot doesn't carry them in store, they don't have that size at OReilly auto parts and you have to order them even from Fastenal. I guess I can't do this impulsively and have to order them from somewhere and do this in 3-5 days.

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Z-Nut Mount for 8mm Trapezoid

description.text:
I had to replace my Printrbot Simple Metal's imperial 1/4" Z-rod and z-nut due to failure of the Delrin z-nut, and printrbot doesnt sell the part anymore. This part allows you to mount a 8mm trapezoid's brass z-nut onto the printrbot.

This mount places the z-nut up against the bottom of the assembly, so push forces are used against the znut-to-bracket. The short bolts are to allow failure if the extruder crashes into the bed or another object.

Requirements:

  • trapezoid 8mm rod + brass nut.
  • 5mm to 8mm coupler
  • 2x button head M3 bolts 6-8mm

DONT FORGET TO RE-CALIBRATE Z TRAVEL WITH M92 COMMAND!!! For me this was "M92 Z269.44"

Calibration:

Set M92 Z to something reasonable, like 269.44

Attach a digital caliper to the Z as pictured, so the depth testing pin can move freely while the caliper body remains in-place. You should be able to do at least 30mm travel.

Raise Z 1mm, using the printer controls, at a time until you make contact with the depth-testing pin. Then zero the caliper.

Raise Z 10mm at a time, then do the math.

New Z Steps = Expected / Observed * Current Z Steps ( Where z steps is your m92 Z setting )

title: side by side refrigerator air baffle damper diffuser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a replacement part for the Air Baffle / Air Damper / Air Diffuser in Whirlpool Side-by-side Refrigerators. This part is known to break at the point where the motor pulls to make it open. This blocks the flow of cold air from the freezer into the refrigerator and prevents it from cooling.

I found detailed replacement/repair instructions in https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/Repairing+Side-by-side+Refrigerator+Diffuser/16423. That guide suggests fixing/gluing the broken part. This design replaces it with a 3D printed one instead.

The design is as close as possible to the original part except for the intentional widening of the area that is prone to break.

I printed it using ABS with 0.1mm resolution and 100% infill. Just installed (Jan 2nd, 2017) in my fridge so no experience yet.

description.text: This is the logo of our company

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:915435

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=915435

Magnetic clip for keeping hose of hydration pack from swinging around. Only piece for bag strap for hose using original Hydrapac which matching piece have on another backpack.

Designed for 11 mm button magnets I had laying around and 15 mm chest strap.

Source file included, change to your needs.

• Remove supports, slide in magnet from side and using screwdriver throw hole in clip push it to front. Test correct magnetic polarization with hose piece.
  • Take magnet to side, apply drop of glue inside and move magnet back. You Just add magnet to front to hold.
    Added second magnet to increase force, no need to glue this one.

Nice example of iterative design

1st prototype: Clip to small, really hard to slide on strap. Too small magnet chamber

2nd prototype: Enlarged magnet chamber and space for strap. Too much material between magnets. Not holding enough. Strap buckle pushing hose of clip.

v3: reduced front side thickness, added offset from strap, second magnet added to newly created space.

title: Robo 3D Modular Spooltop Support With GO Kit

description.text:
This is an updated version of my mod http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:296173 with a lot of new innovation. It can be configured for double sided use to accommodate many different spool sizes using the backers, which screw on with small screws, and can harvested from old filament spools. The foot is designed to strap down with common 1" nylon strap and optionally supports a handle for on-the-go Robo 3D convenience. The handle is 1" schedule 40 PVC pipe which mounts using 1/4-20 bolts. The bed bumper is printed with flexible filament and slides onto your 1" strap.
Also of interest is the optional filament scoop, which acts as a kind of shuttlecock to allow flex in the system. It rides on a 3/16" steel rod, and works very well to deliver smooth, reliable dispensing. Works great with my filament oiler:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1460566
Please post your makes and follow for more Robo 3D mods, coming soon.

Carefully hand thread the bearing spacers. Don't over tighten!

Extra hardware needed:
Standard skatewheel bearings

Optional:
3/16" Steel rod
Small screws for attaching backers and mounting handle interface

title: customizable fan duct including various mount points

description.text:
Not just another fan duct.
This one is fully customizable. even the parts to be exported (fan duct or mount points) are part of the customzier.
I use this one on my prusa with the simple holder and on my M200 with the clamp holder, see foto.
You might download this file to include for local use:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1977298

Just improved the placement of the channels open end
Added rotation to end as well

Just improved the mount point of the duct itself (06.02.2017)

Added optional nut holder to mount points (13.06.2017)

Any modifications suggested please let me know.
